context: Indeed, in our study, H. pylori infection involved the antrum in all cases. However, performing only one biopsy for a rapid urease test in order to reduce gastric biopsy sampling and, consequently, the bleeding risk, may not be adequate. Therefore, applying the present data to clinical practice, histological assessment and the urea breath test may be regarded as clinically equivalent for H. pylori detection in cirrhotics without severe clotting impairment, the choice between the two methods depending on endoscopy requirements, as in the general population. In contrast, the urea breath test is be preferred in cirrhotics with severe clotting impairment to avoid the risk of bleeding following biopsy sampling (Fig. 1 ). In conclusion, the accuracy of the urea breath test for H. pylori diagnosis is very high in cirrhotics, whilst serology and the rapid urease test both give disappointing results. Conflict of interest statement None declared. The 13C-urea breath test (13C-UBT) is a noninvasive, simple and accurate test used to diagnose Helicobacter pylori infection [1–5].
